claim: The cost of food in Canada has decreased since 1970.

supporting.text: According to Statistics Canada, the Consumer Price Index (CPI) for food has increased significantly since 1970, indicating higher food costs.

attacks.text: According to Statistics Canada, the Consumer Price Index (CPI) for food has increased significantly since 1970, indicating higher food costs.
The CPI does not account for changes in food quality, variety, and availability, which have improved since 1970, potentially offsetting perceived cost increases.
Even with improved quality, the CPI's focus on price changes still accurately reflects the monetary cost burden on consumers, which has undeniably risen.
Wage growth and household income increases since 1970 may have outpaced food price inflation, making food effectively more affordable despite higher nominal costs.
Statistics Canada data shows that real food expenditure as a percentage of disposable income has decreased, supporting the claim of decreased effective cost.

supporting.text: Economic data shows that inflation-adjusted food prices in Canada have risen over the past five decades, contradicting the claim.

attacks.text: Economic data shows that inflation-adjusted food prices in Canada have risen over the past five decades, contradicting the claim.
The data may not account for improvements in food quality and variety, which could offset perceived price increases.
Food quality improvements are subjective and do not negate the objective measure of inflation-adjusted price increases.
Regional variations in food prices may mean some areas have seen decreases, even if the national average has risen.
National inflation-adjusted data inherently accounts for regional variations by averaging across the country.

supporting.text: Historical records indicate that food production and distribution costs, including labor and transportation, have increased since 1970, leading to higher retail prices.

attacks.text: Historical records indicate that food production and distribution costs, including labor and transportation, have increased since 1970, leading to higher retail prices.
Technological advancements in agriculture and logistics have significantly reduced per-unit costs, offsetting labor and transportation increases.
While per-unit costs may have decreased, inflation-adjusted data shows overall food prices have risen due to increased demand and supply chain complexities.
Government subsidies and price controls in Canada have kept food prices artificially low despite underlying cost increases.
Subsidies primarily affect staple crops, while most retail food items reflect true market prices, including increased production costs.

supporting.text: Government reports on food affordability demonstrate that Canadians spend a larger proportion of their income on food today compared to 1970.

attacks.text: Government reports on food affordability demonstrate that Canadians spend a larger proportion of their income on food today compared to 1970.
The proportion of income spent on food may have increased due to rising costs in other necessities, not necessarily because food itself is more expensive.
Even if other costs have risen, food prices relative to income still indicate decreased affordability, supporting the original argument.
Government reports may not account for inflation-adjusted food prices, which could show a decrease in real terms.
Inflation-adjusted data still shows higher food costs relative to income, confirming decreased affordability.

supporting.text: Global trends, such as population growth and climate change, have contributed to higher food prices worldwide, including in Canada, since 1970.

attacks.text: Global trends, such as population growth and climate change, have contributed to higher food prices worldwide, including in Canada, since 1970.
Technological advancements in agriculture have significantly increased food production efficiency, offsetting some of the price pressures from global trends.
Government subsidies and trade policies in Canada have helped stabilize food prices despite global inflationary pressures.
The Canadian dollar's depreciation since 1970 has made imported food more expensive, contributing to higher overall food costs.
Domestic food production in Canada has increased, reducing reliance on imports and mitigating the impact of currency fluctuations.
